chargeHist.descr: Operating While Revoked (Rev due to alc/contr subst/refusal)
Operating While Revoked (Rev due to alc/contr subst/refusal)
Operate with Restricted Controlled Substance (5th or 6th)

result.execSummary:
The defendant Robert A. Wilkinson was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case. One or more other charges in this case were dismissed. The dismissed charges were not proven and have no legal effect. Robert A. Wilkinson is presumed innocent of the dismissed charges.

  • Robert A. Wilkinson was found guilty of OWI 6th, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
AMENDED 9/19/17.   Days of credit granted.  AMENDED 9/29/17.  Days of credit granted corrected.
Concurrent with: Sentence now serving.

superMiscConds.notes:
If agent recommends, defendant must attend and successfully complete an alcohol assessment and comply with any recommended treatment.  Defendant is to execute any releases necessary for agent to verify compliance.

Defendant to be subject to random testing by his agent.

If agent recommends, defendant must attend and successfully complete a drug assessment, and comply with any recommended treatment.  Defendant to execute any releases necessary for agent to verify compliance.

Defendant to be subject to random testing by his agent.
Comply with all mental health recommendations of his treatment providers.

Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.

Not to possess or consume any controlled substances.   Not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  Not to possess any prescription medications of any kind unless those have been prescribed to the defendant by a physician, and in that case, the defendant shall take such medications only as prescribed.  Defendant shall not alter the form of any prescription prior to, or in conjunction with, ingestion.

Defendant shall have no contact, directly or indirectly, either personally, by mail, telephone or through any other person,or by any other means with Charles Redcloud.  AMENDED 9/29/17.  Contact with Charles Redcloud is at the agent's discretion.  

Defendant shall not operate a motor vehicle on the highways until properly licensed.

The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by a risk and needs assessment and the agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with extended supervision conditions.

To be paid on a monthly basis while on extended supervision.  Outstanding financial obligations shall be collected pursuant to statutory provisions, including deductions from inmate prison monies.  If reconfined or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.   If the defendant is placed on probation or released to extended supervision, IT IS ORDERED that the defendant pay supervision fees as determined by the Department of Corrections.

supervisions.notes: Per Statute 343.301(g) your operating privileges for operation of Class D vehicles will require that vehicles owned and/or driven by you be equipped with an ignition interlock device.  Must install a mandatory Ignition Interlock Device when defendant obtains an occupational license or regular license.  There is a $50 ignition interlock surcharge imposed.

records.descr: Order for intox driver assessment and safety plan

records.addlTxt:
DA Gerald Fox appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person, in custody, with Attorney Niemeier.  Defendant plead no contest to count 2, OWI 6th.  Count 1, and 16TR910, dismissed but read in for sentencing purposes.  Count 3 dismissed by operation of law.   Court recited the charges and possible penalties on the count he plead to.  Defendant understood.  Priors confirmed by the court with the defendant and counsel.  Felony warnings given. He understood.  Court reviewed the plea questionnaire, constitutional rights and elements with the defendant.  Defense stipulated that there is a factual basis for the plea.   Court found that the defendant freely, voluntarily, knowingly and intelligently entered his plea and waived his constitutional rights.  Court found that a factual basis exists for the plea.  Found guilty of OWI 6th, contrary to 346.63(1)(a).  State recommended:  18 months initial confinement,  followed by extended supervision.  Concurrent with the sentence he is now serving.  24 month revocation and IID.  $600.00 fine, plus costs.  Not eligible for CIP.  Eligible for SAR.    Joint recommendation.  

Court ordered:  18 months initial confinement, 3 years extended supervision.  Total 4- 1/2 years.  .  Concurrent with the sentence he is now serving in 13CF37.  24 month revocation and IID.  $600.00 fine, plus costs.  Pay while on extended supervision.   Not eligible for CIP.  Eligible for SAP.  Comply with all mental health recommendations of his treatment providers.    Defendant shall not consume any alcohol unless a physician states in writing that the defendant is alcohol dependent and complete withdrawal could endanger the defendant's health or life. In this case a doctor's excuse must be submitted to the Jackson County Clerk of Court or the Jackson County Jail within 48 hours of the bond being signed. Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, bar areas of restaurants, or where available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.    Not to possess or consume any controlled substances.   Not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  Not to possess any prescription medications of any kind unless those have been prescribed to the defendant by a physician, and in that case, the defendant shall take such medications only as prescribed.  Defendant shall not alter the form of any prescription prior to, or in conjunction with, ingestion.    Defendant shall not operate a motor vehicle on the highways until properly licensed.    The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by a risk and needs assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.  AODA and recommended treatment.  CC    Court advised defendant of the DNA submission requirement.  No contact with C.R.
Plea hearing on February 20, 2017 at 10:00 am.
STC canceled at set for PLEA at request of Atty Niemeier; ok'd with DA's office.
Status conference on January 11, 2017 at 08:45 am.

DA Gerald Fox appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person, in custody, with Attorney Niemeier.  Parties have the report.  Defense not challenging the findings.  Court found defendant special plea is not supported.  STC set for 1/11 at 8:45 am.
Competency hearing on December 8, 2016 at 01:30 pm.
STC canceled and set for further hrg at request of Atty Niemeier.

From attorney Niemeier to Court requesting 11-21 STC be adjourned and case be set for competency hearing.
(routed to Judge after scanning)
Order for Examination under Sec. 971.16 (not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect)
Status conference on November 21, 2016 at 03:00 pm.
Reading waived.  Defendant entered NGI plea.  Court ordered evaluation due  11/7/16.  STC set for 11/21 at 3 pm.  Bond continued.
Information filed with the court.

DA Fox appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person, in custody, with Attorney Niemeier.  Court questioned defendant on his understanding of the waiver of preliminary hearing.  He stated he understood.  Court found that the defendant knowingly and intelligently waived his right to have a preliminary hearing.  Probable cause found.
STC canceled and set for WP at request of Atty Niemeier's office; ok'd with DA's office.
Waiver of Prelim on October 4, 2016 at 02:30 pm.
Status conference on September 26, 2016 at 03:00 pm.

DA Gerald Fox appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person, in custody, with Attorneys Niemeier and Attorney Yonko.  Judges Goodman and Becker presiding.  Judge Goodman has read the report.  Defendant has regained competency.  Attorney Yonko does not have an objection to the report.  Concerned if he is incarcerated, he will lose his medications.  State agrees there is a risk of losing competency, unless he has an adequate supply of the medications when he is incarcerated.  Discussion on medications availability at the Jackson County Sherrif's Dept.   Defendant has a 30 day supply of medications with him.   Attorney Yonko requests the hearing be postponed.  Attorney Niemeier has same concerns regarding medications.  DA Fox called Capt. S.B.  He is now present in court.  Discussion held off the record.  Adjourn for Capt. B. to discuss with Jail nurse.  Back on the record.  Attorney Yonko has concern that defendant has access to doctors.  Off the record.  Resume back on the record.  Capt. B. returned.  Conferred with jail nursing staff.  Can take care of medications by tomorrow.  None of the medications are prohibited.  Would be able to administer medications 4 times a day.  13CF37. Court finds that the defendant is competent.  May return to ALJ.  Judge Becker questioned whether defendant will stay or return to facility.  Defendant not contesting competency in 16CF35.  Find competent in 16CF35.  Defendant will change plea to NGI in 16CF35.  Schedule for preliminary hearing.  STC set for 9/26/16 at 3:00 pm.  Will want to know if case should be set for a waiver of prelim. or a preliminary hearing.  Bond continued.
Competency hearing on September 22, 2016 at 03:00 pm.
STC canceled and set for CH.
paper copies to attorneys.  Copy sent electronically to Judge Becker, on 9/12.
Status conference on October 3, 2016 at 03:00 pm.

DA Gerald Fox appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared through Attorney Niemeier.  Has been found incompetent.  Hold in abeyance.  Re-evaluate at 90 day intervals and within 30 days of release.  Court adopted recommendation.  Suspend proceedings.  Track with 13CF case.
Status conference on July 11, 2016 at 03:00 pm.
DA Gerald Fox appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared through Attorney Niemeier.  Defense needs more time.  Schedule STC on 7/11 at 3 p.m.  Attorney Niemeier may be a little late.
JA gave a copy to the Judge.
for Competency Examination by DHS.
Status conference on June 27, 2016 at 03:00 pm.
from Attorney Niemeier.  Requesting competency evaluation for defendant.
Status conference on June 13, 2016 at 03:00 pm.

NO appearance by defendant.  Counsel Rick Niemeier appears for defendant.  DA Fox present for the State.  The blood test is not back yet.  Status requested in 30 days.  STC 6-13-16 at 3:00.  TR continues to track.
Rescheduled for 2 weeks at request of defendant's atty, Rick Niemeyer. Awaiting blood alcohol test report.
Status conference on May 2, 2016 at 03:00 pm.
Blood test cost from WSP.  $75.00

In this case a doctor's excuse must be submitted to the Jackson County Clerk of Court or the Jackson County Jail within 48 hours of the bond being signed. Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, bar areas of restaurants, or where available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.
